docs.lead_paragraph: For Kristie Wolek, the trouble started about a year ago, when her periods became so heavy that the blood loss made her severely anemic. She was exhausted all the time. The problem was caused by four fibroids, benign tumors in her uterus that had been tiny and harmless for more than a decade but had recently begun growing rapidly. Two doctors recommended a hysterectomy, an operation to remove the uterus and the only sure cure for fibroids. Though Ms. Wolek, 43, did not want to have more children, she did not want a hysterectomy, either. But she thought she had no choice.

headline.main: A Less Invasive Alternative for Fibroids

docs.abstract: Hysterectomy alternatives are being offered to patients with fibroid tumors; minimally invasive procedure, called fibroid embolization, shrinks fibroids by blocking their blood supply; drawing (M)

docs.section_name: Technology; Theater; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: JAYLEN CARR drooled, wailed and burped in his mother's arms a day after being delivered here at Saddleback Memorial Medical Center. With unfocused eyes and powerful lungs, he looked and sounded like a lot of other day-old infants. So when the nurse entered the room, she carried a handheld scanner to make sure that Jaylen had not been accidentally switched with another child in the maternity ward. She scanned a data chip on one of Jaylen's hospital identity bracelets, then did the same to his mother, Jacquelyn Carr, who was in bed looking happy but tired.

headline.main: Maternity Ward Fashions: Knit Caps, Chip ID's and Bar Codes

docs.abstract: Increasing number of hospitals are using scanning technology in maternity wards to bar mix-ups and abductions of newborns; electronic security devices have drawbacks, including high cost, failures and false alarms; photo (M)
